instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CHGR_PHASE: What is CHGR_PHASE? CHGR_PHASE is charger voltage chopped up into individual slices prior to smoothing where it becomes PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ?
threads.message:
Hi Guys.
Working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no power no green light. Liquid damaged in the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR> area.
I replaced both of those components and surrounding caps/resistors. 
Found a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> that I tracked down to <SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL> on <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>, when I removed it the short went away. I also replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> & <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> for good measure. 
Connected adapter and got green light but <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was low 6.34V. It slowly went down to 0V and the short returned. 
I replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> again to rule out bad placement. Same symptoms. 
Here is what I am noticing now....if I test for a short at <SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL> on <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> the short shows for a few seconds then is gone. I also get these results if I test <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R5481</RESISTOR> as well .It is like the short is "moving" from one end of the circuit to the other.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shows a short then <SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL> doesn't and vice versa.
I am stumped. Any suggestions ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ?
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ?
threads.message:
Uhm this is a PPBUS short and has nothing to do with the sponge cap.....

You need to replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>/30 all together at once. But it does sound like the gate of <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>/30 has no continuity to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> so you can "activate" the FET with your multimeter and cause a short because you enabled the FET by measuring on the gate. I suspect corroded trace to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ?
threads.message:
Hi Duke.
I confirmed continuity between <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>/30 and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, those traces are good. I took some diode mode readings at <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> while it was removed. Not sure if these can help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ?
threads.message:
Replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and the FETs all at once. No more short but <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is only 0.080V. I am not getting a blinking green light on the magesafe.
Resistance between pin 17/18 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is 3 ohms. Think it should be 2 right ? So I replaced <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/52. Same results
Resistance between 27/28 is sitting right at 20 ohms.
What am I missing ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ?
threads.message: Found <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> to be blown. Replaced it and the board powered on and then died with in 10 seconds. Green light faded away and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> short returned until I removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> again. Something on the circuit is blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> and creating a short but I cant figure out what it is.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ?
threads.message: I can only advice to check all traces and resistors around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Traces to <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/35 are still suspect are traces to <CAPACITOR>C7025</CAPACITOR>. <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> will probably be dead again and both FETs too.
